title: jackg
author: jackg
created_time: November 11, 2022, 05:22:10 AMLast edit: November 11, 2022, 05:50:18 AM by jackg
content: Not sure if there's already discussions on things like this but I constantly find I'm left with unanswered questions when reading crypto related media, often news articles (and some of my questions never get answered).I've been thinking this about the ftx hack fund issues and have been wondering if there's a good place a lot of people use to get accurate and quick information about breaking news and information that comes quickly? Are places like Twitter good for this? I've seen it be used and is quite useful for cyber vulnerabilities where people post threads with 15+ tweets that are concise enough to cover most things.Before my issues with not finding the full answers on what happened with ftx, I had a similar problem with taproot where I had to look up how it functioned multiple times before it finally clicked (and that was a case of it making sense how it worked by the sites I found but then they didn't have any examples of it and left it being explained in an abstract way - has anyone found a solution to this or do we just have to wait on it or become the solution)?

comments.body: Quote from: jackg on November 11, 2022, 05:22:10 AMI've been thinking this about the ftx hackFirst off: FTX didn't get hacked. The CEO just went full degenerate and took too much unnecessary risk for such a striving company.Quote from: jackg on November 11, 2022, 05:22:10 AMAre places like Twitter good for this? I've seen it be used and is quite useful for cyber vulnerabilities where people post threads with 15+ tweets that are concise enough to cover most things.In my opinion Twitter is still the best place for this. Of course you can't know with 100% certainty until the dusk settles, but news and rumours mostly break out on Twitter first, and that there are reputable people there where you can put a lot of trust(not like 100% trust, but with low likeliness of false information) on the information they provide.

comments.author: Accardo
comments.body: Since you read cryptocurrency news sites, always look up their writers on twitter and follow them. Especially the bitcoin magazine, Forbes, and coindesk writers. They have a strong control of cryptocurrency news even before it appear on blogs. Sometimes they tweet to get responses before writing about the topic. On the other hand, a lot of cryptocurrency projects are active on twitter, so announcements appear on twitter first and the writers can retweet the announcement for awareness. They can tweet about the trend if need arises before writing about it. Therefore, twitter is like a place to get the raw information from the horse's mouth.

comments.body: Depending on the topic you're looking for, you better find specific website or newsletter. For example, i use https://bitcoinops.org/ for Bitcoin technical news/information.Quote from: rat03gopoh on November 11, 2022, 05:58:53 AMWhat about news aggregators? https://cryptopanic.comI checked that website and IMO it's not really helpful for OP. I'd recommend https://defidive.com/news instead which have better categorization (media news, twitter and youtube) and filter that is easier to use/understand.
